newsitem.title: USA: COMEX copper ends weaker on light fund selling.
newsitem.headline: COMEX copper ends weaker on light fund selling.

text.p: COMEX copper ended weaker breaking through trendline support, but rebounding on light trade buying, dealers said.
The breakthrough of support at 105.00 cents a lb in September on light fund selling looked bearish initially, but arbitrage and trade buying took the market right back up by the close."
"The trend is higher," said Joe Rosta, director of research for CPM Group. "Demand is stronger in the United States and Europe, strong enough to take prices higher."
He downplayed the increasing London Metal Exchange warehouse stock increase of the last eight weeks as a function of arbitrage and slow seasonal demand, which "will pick up after Labor Day."

Other traders disagreed, believing the high stocks would eventually weigh down on the market. "There's a lot of copper around," said one commission house broker. "We expect a lot more coming onto the warehouses, which should weigh down on the market."
London Metal Exchange warehouse stocks increased another 1,700 tonnes to 250,400 tonnes, while the LME cash-to-three-month backwardation was steady at $18/$22 a tonne.

On the fundamental side of the market, striking union workers at Falconbridge Ltd's Sudbury complex, represented by the Canadian Auto Workers, are waiting on a response from the company on a new proposal on shift scheduling to the company.
The strike has entered its second week.
((Derek J. Caney, New York Commodity Desk, 212-859-1646))
